title: Audi’s Grand Tourer joins the 300 club
text:
Tony Davis Motoring Writer Oct 4, 2019 — 12.00am Share

These are boom times for Audi Sport and its most prominent competitors, the BMW M Division and Mercedes-AMG. The world seemingly can’t get enough of high-performance German luxury cars. Audi Sport, for example, plans to double its output by 2023.

Its latest creation is the Audi RS7 Sportback, an ultra-heated version of the second-generation A7 five-door hatch/sedan which was released in Australia late last year.

The 4-litre twin-turbo V8 delivers the goods; the rear steering system and other features help maintain stability.

The new RS7 can take five occupants (one more than before) at speeds of up to 305 km/h. More dramatic than its top speed is the rapidity with which it ramps up its pace.

We picked up an example at Frankfurt airport and, within about 10 minutes, hit a non-restricted segment of a billiard table-smooth autobahn. The 120 km/h allowed until then felt like a cantor and, with a mighty V8 roar, in what seemed like no time at all, we were exceeding 250. Most roads can feel a little narrow at those speeds, but the car itself remained rock solid and would have happily kept accelerating if not for the clusters of traffic we kept catching.

Which sort of tells you that even in Germany you can rarely reach this car’s potential, while in Australia…

I didn’t test the claim, but an engineer told me it is safe to do a hasty double-lane change at 300 km/h.

The car’s normal top speed is electronically limited to 250. It’s the optional “dynamic package plus” with carbon-ceramic brakes and other upgrades that unlocks the 305 speed, and a large number of Australians ticked that box with the previous model.

Like almost all German high-performance cars, the RS7 is majestic under heavy braking, which is an imperative if you are storming down autobahns.

Due to reach its first Australian customers in mid-2020, it is differentiated by an aero bodykit and other exterior enhancements. The guards have been flared to accommodate wider wheels (that wasn’t the case on the previous model) and, for the first time with any RS, there are different door skins to the donor car. These have a prominent ridge along them which serves to pull the visual weight down and give the car a lower, longer look. The same treatment has been given to the RS7’s A6-wagon based RS6 stablemate, due here about the same time.
description: If you need to transport five people at five kilometres a minute, the RS7 Sportback is for you.
